markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

seattlepi.com  (WEB - en-US)

A website providing news about Seattle, Washington, and the digital brand of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer newspaper, which ceased publication as a print product in 2009.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The site is owned by Hearst Communications, a New York-based private company that owns a mix of television stations, magazines, and over 80 daily and weekly newspapers in the United States. Its other prominent newspaper brands include the Houston Chronicle, the San Francisco Chronicle, and the Albany Times-Union. Hearst generates revenue from advertising and subscriptions to its printed and digital products.

Content

A small staff of journalists creates news and feature articles and videos about the Seattle, Washington, area. Content is also provided by other Hearst outlets and The Associated Press.

The site organizes content by several tabs, including Business, Sports, Travel, and Real Estate.

Credibility

Articles on the site are balanced and well-sourced. Headlines are measured and accurately reflect the content. Text and video content is attributed either to the site’s staff journalists or to a third-party content provider. The site does not articulate a corrections policy, but articles that contained errors are published under a Correction heading, and the error is described. The site separates opinion from news content.

Transparency

Reporters and editors are listed on the site, along with brief biographies and contact information, including email addresses, social media handles, and telephone numbers. The site identifies and provides contact information for managers, and solicits user feedback. Advertising and sponsored content are clearly labeled. Hearst’s ownership is disclosed, and the site includes a detailed history of the Post Intelligencer.

History

The outlet traces its history to 1863, when Seattle entrepreneur J.R. Watson founded The Gazette, which later became the Seattle Post-Intelligencer. Hearst purchased the newspaper in 1921. Seattlepi.com served as the online presence of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer. The paper ceased publishing in 2009, converting to an online-only news service. The site said the transition marked “the first major metro daily newspaper to go online-only.” The website was registered in 1999.

Written by:
Dan Cook

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Eric Effron
